elements.content: Aiming at the targeted construction of coordination polymer luminophores, the engineering of host–guest architectures with charge transfer based emissions is performed by utilizing the interactions between the electron-deficient 2,4,6-tri­(pyridin-4-yl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) and electron-rich polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) motifs as acceptors and donors, respectively. Through guest modulation of a prototype coordination polymer [Cd­(tpt)­(1,4-pda)­(H2O)2]·(tpt)·(H2O)2 (1) (1,4-H2pda = 1,4-phenylene­diacetic acid), a series of coordination polymers with different PAHs as guests, [Cd2(tpt)2(1,4-pda)2]·guest (2–5) (guest = triphenylene for 2, pyrene for 3, coronene for 4, and perylene for 5), are successfully fabricated. Distinct from 1, coordination polymers 2–5 reveal unique bilayer structures with PAHs interlayer and good stability, owing to the enhanced stacking interactions between tpt motifs and PAH guests. Moreover, their emissions cover a wide range of wavelength due to the effective guest to host charge transfer interactions between donor and acceptor motifs. Their readily tunable host–guest charge transfer based emissions make them good candidates as potential luminophores.
elements.clean_text: Aiming at the targeted construction of coordination polymer luminophores, the engineering of host-guest architectures with charge transfer based emissions is performed by utilizing the interactions between the electron-deficient 2,4,6-tri(pyridin-4-yl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) and electron-rich polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) motifs as acceptors and donors, respectively. Through guest modulation of a prototype coordination polymer [Cd(tpt)(1,4-pda)(H2O)2]⋅(tpt)⋅(H2O)2 (1) (1,4-H2pda = 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid), a series of coordination polymers with different PAHs as guests, [Cd2(tpt)2(1,4-pda)2]⋅guest (2-5) (guest = triphenylene for 2, pyrene for 3, coronene for 4, and perylene for 5), are successfully fabricated. Distinct from 1, coordination polymers 2-5 reveal unique bilayer structures with PAHs interlayer and good  stability, owing to the enhanced stacking interactions between tpt motifs and PAH guests. Moreover, their emissions cover a wide range of wavelength due to the effective guest to host charge transfer interactions between donor and acceptor motifs. Their readily tunable host-guest charge transfer based emissions make them good candidates as potential luminophores.

elements.content: In recent years, luminescent coordination polymers (LCPs) have attracted considerable interest as solid state lighting devices for their readily tailorable structures and properties based on their modularized architectures, which provides a significant platform for the development of luminophore, sensor, optical device, and so on. Aiming at the targeted modulation of LCPs as luminophores, much efforts have been made in the rational design of organic linkers and choice of metal centers with specific emissions. On the other hand, host–guest chemistry has promoted a brand new stage for the construction of LCPs, since functional guests with specific optical properties can be straightforwardly embedded into coordination polymers via various host–guest interactions, such as hydrogen bonding interaction, π–π stacking interaction, electrostatic interaction, and so on. Moreover, the emissions of generated LCPs are mainly deriving from the host framework or the guest when energy transfer occurs or the simple superposition of both when their emissions are relatively independent. In contrast to these ordinary conditions, host–guest charge transfer (HGCT) based emissions are more attractive for its advantages in readily tunable emissions by modulating donors and acceptors. However, the emission properties of LCPs based on HGCT are few explored to some extent, due to the relatively harsh prerequisite of suitable donors and acceptors and their proper arrangements that determine the occurrence of charge transfer between them. Therefore, the achievement of LCPs as luminophores with highly tunable HGCT based emission is still a challenge in this field.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, luminescent coordination polymers (LCPs) have attracted considerable interest as solid state lighting devices for their readily tailorable structures and properties based on their modularized architectures, which provides a significant platform for the development of luminophore, sensor, optical device, and so on. Aiming at the targeted modulation of LCPs as luminophores, much efforts have been made in the rational design of organic linkers and choice of metal centers with specific emissions. On the other hand, host-guest chemistry has promoted a brand new stage for the construction of LCPs, since functional guests with specific optical properties can be straightforwardly embedded into coordination polymers via various host-guest interactions, such as hydrogen bonding interaction, π-π stacking interaction, electrostatic interaction, and so on. Moreover, the emissions of generated LCPs are mainly deriving from the host framework or the guest when energy transfer occurs or the simple superposition of both when their emissions are relatively independent. In contrast to these ordinary conditions, host-guest charge transfer (HGCT) based emissions are more attractive for its advantages in readily tunable emissions by modulating donors and acceptors. However, the emission properties of LCPs based on HGCT are few explored to some extent, due to the relatively harsh prerequisite of suitable donors and acceptors and their proper arrangements that determine the occurrence of charge transfer between them. Therefore, the achievement of LCPs as luminophores with highly tunable HGCT based emission is still a challenge in this field.

elements.content: To gain LCPs with HGCT based emissions, we have focused on the host–guest engineering between electron-deficient and electron-rich motifs as acceptors and donors, respectively. Among the numerous potential acceptor motifs, triazine, as a remarkable functional group, has captured our attentions due to its typical electron-deficient and remarkable face-to-face π–π stacking characteristics, which favors to generation of charge transfer process and the assembly of coordination polymers effectively. 2,4,6-Tri­(pyridin-4-yl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt), as a typical electron-deficient tridentate ligand including traizine motif, has been utilized as an efficient electron-acceptor building block for the construction of various coordination polymers in various applications, such as photochromic materials and photoreaction molecular containers. Moreover, discrete cages and polymers including tpt and electron-rich PAH guests have been reported, which promises the potential in construction of donor–acceptor LCP systems with HGCT based emissions.
elements.clean_text: To gain LCPs with HGCT based emissions, we have focused on the host-guest engineering between electron-deficient and electron-rich motifs as acceptors and donors, respectively. Among the numerous potential acceptor motifs, triazine, as a remarkable functional group, has captured our attentions due to its typical electron-deficient and remarkable face-to-face π-π stacking characteristics, which favors to generation of charge transfer process and the assembly of coordination polymers effectively. 2,4,6-Tri(pyridin-4-yl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt), as a typical electron-deficient tridentate ligand including traizine motif, has been utilized as an efficient electron-acceptor building block for the construction of various coordination polymers in various applications, such as photochromic materials and photoreaction molecular containers. Moreover, discrete cages and polymers including tpt and electron-rich PAH guests have been reported, which promises the potential in construction of donor-acceptor LCP systems with HGCT based emissions.

elements.content: Considering all the points mentioned above, we have made continuous efforts on the study of HGCT based LCPs involving tpt–PAH systems. Herein, we report the host–guest engineering and charge transfer based emissions in a tpt–PAH LCP system (). Utilizing the tpt–PAH stacking interactions, PAHs could be readily inserted interlayer of a prototype 2D coordination polymer, [Cd­(tpt)­(1,4-pda)­(H2O)2]·(tpt)·(H2O)2 (1) (1,4-H2pda = 1,4-phenylene­diacetic acid). The resultant coordination polymers, [Cd2(tpt)2(1,4-pda)2]·guest (2–5) (guest = triphenylene for 2, pyrene for 3, coronene for 4, and perylene for 5), reveal unique 2D bilayer structures, good water stability. More importantly, HGCT emissions are achieved by the combination of tpt acceptors and PAH donors. Moreover, the emission properties of these coordination polymers can be rationally modulated in wide range through the wise choice of guests with proper ionization potentials. All characters make these LCPs potential luminophores, which also proves the validity of host guest engineering in coordination polymers for the construction of luminophores.
elements.clean_text: Considering all the points mentioned above, we have made continuous efforts on the study of HGCT based LCPs involving tpt-PAH systems. Herein, we report the host-guest engineering and charge transfer based emissions in a tpt-PAH LCP system (). Utilizing the tpt-PAH stacking interactions, PAHs could be readily inserted interlayer of a prototype 2D coordination polymer, [Cd(tpt)(1,4-pda)(H2O)2]⋅(tpt)⋅(H2O)2 (1) (1,4-H2pda = 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid). The resultant coordination polymers, [Cd2(tpt)2(1,4-pda)2]⋅guest (2-5) (guest = triphenylene for 2, pyrene for 3, coronene for 4, and perylene for 5), reveal unique 2D bilayer structures, good water stability. More importantly, HGCT emissions are achieved by the combination of tpt acceptors and PAH donors. Moreover, the emission properties of these coordination polymers can be rationally modulated in wide range through the wise choice of guests with proper ionization potentials. All characters make these LCPs potential luminophores, which also proves the validity of host guest engineering in coordination polymers for the construction of luminophores.

elements.clean_text: 1  Targeted Construction of Donor-Acceptor Architecture with Electron-Deficient tpt and Electron-Rich PAH Building Blocks (Triphenylene as a Representative of PAHs) for Effective Charge Transfer Based Emissions

elements.content: All reagents were commercially purchased and used without further purification. The tpt ligand was synthesized according to the previous literature. The elemental analyses were carried out on a vario EL CUBE elemental analyzer. Thermal stability studies were measured on a TG8121 thermoanalyzer. The phase purities of these five samples were confirmed by X-ray powder diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The IR spectra were recorded by a BRUKER TENSOR 37 spectrophotometer with pressed KBr pellets. The UV–vis spectra were recorded by a SHIMADZU UV-3600 spectrophotometer. The luminescence spectra were measured with a Hitachi F4500 luminescence spectrophotometer. The emission quantum yield and decay lifetime were measured with an Edinburgh FLS980 fluorescence spectrophotometer under air at room temperature. Luminescent images were obtained by using an automated Leica DM5000B microscope equipped with different filter cubes (filter cube A for coordination polymers 1–4: 340–380 nm bandpass (BP) excitation filter, 400 nm dichroic mirror, and 425 nm long-pass (LP) emission filter; filter cube N2.1 for coordination polymer 5: 515–560 BP excitation filter, 580 nm dichroic mirror, and 425 nm LP emissions filter).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All reagents were commercially purchased and used without further purification. The tpt ligand was synthesized according to the previous literature. The elemental analyses were carried out on a vario EL CUBE elemental analyzer. Thermal stability studies were measured on a TG8121 thermoanalyzer. The phase purities of these five samples were confirmed by X-ray powder diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The IR spectra were recorded by a BRUKER TENSOR 37 spectrophotometer with pressed KBr pellets. The UV-vis spectra were recorded by a SHIMADZU UV-3600 spectrophotometer. The luminescence spectra were measured with a Hitachi F4500 luminescence spectrophotometer. The emission quantum yield and decay lifetime were measured with an Edinburgh FLS980 fluorescence spectrophotometer under air at room temperature. Luminescent images were obtained by using an automated Leica DM5000B microscope equipped with different filter cubes (filter cube A for coordination polymers 1-4: 340-380 nm bandpass (BP) excitation filter, 400 nm dichroic mirror, and 425 nm long-pass (LP) emission filter; filter cube N2.1 for coordination polymer 5: 515-560 BP excitation filter, 580 nm dichroic mirror, and 425 nm LP emissions filter).

elements.content: For the syntheses of [Cd­(tpt)­(1,4-pda)­(H2O)2]·(tpt)·(H2O)2 (1), a mixture of Cd­(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol), 1,4-H2pda (0.1 mmol), and tpt (0.05 mmol) in DMF (6 mL), H2O (2 mL), and ethanol (2 mL) mixed solvents was placed in a 20 mL glass vial and sealed. The vial was heated at 95 °C for 24 h, and then colorless crystals were obtained (65% yield based on tpt). EA Calcd (%) for C46H40CdN12O8: C, 55.18; H, 4.03; N, 16.79. Found: C, 55.14; H, 4.45; N, 16.62. FT-IR (KBr, 3500–4000 cm–1): 3546 (m), 3431 (m), 3048 (m), 1571 (s), 1516 (s), 1419 (m), 1370 (m), 1315 (m), 1146 (w), 1062 (w), 1012 (w), 803 (s), 713 (s), 665 (s), 642 (s).
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses of Coordination Polymers

For the syntheses of [Cd(tpt)(1,4-pda)(H2O)2]⋅(tpt)⋅(H2O)2 (1), a mixture of Cd(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (0.1 mmol), 1,4-H2pda (0.1 mmol), and tpt (0.05 mmol) in DMF (6 mL), H2O (2 mL), and ethanol (2 mL) mixed solvents was placed in a 20 mL glass vial and sealed. The vial was heated at 95 °C for 24 h, and then colorless crystals were obtained (65% yield based on tpt). EA Calcd (%) for C46H40CdN12O8: C, 55.18; H, 4.03; N, 16.79. Found: C, 55.14; H, 4.45; N, 16.62. FT-IR (KBr, 3500-4000 cm-1): 3546 (m), 3431 (m), 3048 (m), 1571 (s), 1516 (s), 1419 (m), 1370 (m), 1315 (m), 1146 (w), 1062 (w), 1012 (w), 803 (s), 713 (s), 665 (s), 642 (s).

elements.content: For the syntheses of [Cd2(tpt)2(1,4-pda)2]·guest (2–5), similar procedures to that of 1 were applied, with the introduction of corresponding guest (0.05 mmol) into the reaction systems. For 2 (guest = triphenylene), light green crystals were obtained. Yield: 60% (based on tpt). EA Calcd (%) for C74H52Cd2N12O8: C, 60.79; H, 3.58; N, 11.50. Found: C, 60.92; H, 3.81; N, 11.03. FT-IR (KBr, 3500–4000 cm–1): 3079 (m), 3050 (m), 3035 (m), 2970 (m), 2931 (m), 1611 (m), 1566 (s), 1517 (s), 1439 (m), 1373 (m), 1313 (m), 1140 (w), 1061 (w), 1012 (w), 800 (s), 752 (s), 667 (s), 642 (s). For 3 (guest = pyrene), orange crystals were obtained. Yield: 50% (based on tpt). EA Calcd for C72H50Cd2N12O8: C, 62.22; H, 3.51; N, 11.70. Found: C, 62.54; H, 3.26; N, 11.17. FT-IR (KBr, 3500–4000 cm–1): 3050 (m), 3032 (m), 2965 (m), 2928 (m), 1610 (m), 1552 (s), 1511 (s), 1434 (m), 1383 (m), 1313 (m), 1145 (w), 1060 (w), 1015 (w), 797 (s), 769 (s), 667 (s), 642 (s). For 4 (guest = coronene), orange crystals were obtained. Yield: 62% (based on tpt). EA Calcd for C80H52Cd2N12O8: C, 62.63; H, 3.41; N, 10.96. Found: C, 62.24; H, 3.56; N, 9.77. FT-IR (KBr, 3500–4000 cm–1): 3050 (m), 2967 (m), 2930 (m), 1611 (m), 1566 (s), 1516 (s), 1440 (m), 1385 (m), 1313 (m), 1142 (w), 1064 (w), 1012 (w), 799 (s), 726 (s), 667 (s), 642 (s). For 5 (guest = perylene), red crystals were obtained. Yield: 55% (based on tpt). EA Calcd for C76H54Cd2N12O8: C, 61.33; H, 3.66; N, 11.29. Found: C, 62.04; H, 3.35; N, 10.57. FT-IR (KBr, 3500–4000 cm–1): 3050 (m), 3030 (m), 2962 (m), 2928 (m), 1609 (m), 1557 (s), 1517 (s), 1437 (m), 1373 (m), 1313 (m), 1140 (w), 1061 (w), 1013 (w), 799 (s), 766 (s), 667 (s), 642 (s).

For 2 (guest = triphenylene), light green crystals were obtained. Yield: 60% (based on tpt). EA Calcd (%) for C74H52Cd2N12O8: C, 60.79; H, 3.58; N, 11.50. Found: C, 60.92; H, 3.81; N, 11.03. For 5 (guest = perylene), red crystals were obtained. Yield: 55% (based on tpt). EA Calcd for C76H54Cd2N12O8: C, 61.33; H, 3.66; N, 11.29. Found: C, 62.04; H, 3.35; N, 10.57. FT-IR (KBr, 3500-4000 cm-1): 3050 (m), 3030 (m), 2962 (m), 2928 (m), 1609 (m), 1557 (s), 1517 (s), 1437 (m), 1373 (m), 1313 (m), 1140 (w), 1061 (w), 1013 (w), 799 (s), 766 (s), 667 (s), 642 (s).

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray analyses of coordination polymers 1, 2, and 4 were performed on a Bruker Smart CCD area diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.7107 Å), with the φ and ω scan mode. The SADABS program is applied to absorption correction. The structures are solved by direct methods followed with successive difference Fourier methods. All non-hydrogen atoms are refined anisotropically. Computations are performed using XShell, and final full-matrix refinements are against F 2. The crystallographic data of 1, 2, and 4 are listed in Table S1, and their CCDC numbers are 1511442–1511444, respectively. For 1, the free tpt molecules located in the channels show oriented disorder. Upon introducing pyrene and perylene into reaction system, 3 and 5 are obtained, respectively, but cannot be characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction due to the poor crystalline quality of crystal samples caused by the characteristic of twin crystal of the samples. Nevertheless, by comparing their PXRD patterns, thermogravimetry curves, and elemental analyses results to those of coordination polymers 2 and 4, we conclude that coordination polymers 3 and 5 shall have similar host–guest structures to that of 2 and 4.
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal X-ray Crystallography Studies

Single crystal X-ray analyses of coordination polymers 1, 2, and 4 were performed on a Bruker Smart CCD area diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.7107 Å), with the φ and ω scan mode. The SADABS program is applied to absorption correction. The structures are solved by direct methods followed with successive difference Fourier methods. All non-hydrogen atoms are refined anisotropically. Computations are performed using XShell, and final full-matrix refinements are against F 2. The crystallographic data of 1, 2, and 4 are listed in Table S1, and their CCDC numbers are 1511442-1511444, respectively. For 1, the free tpt molecules located in the channels show oriented disorder. Upon introducing pyrene and perylene into reaction system, 3 and 5 are obtained, respectively, but cannot be characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction due to the poor crystalline quality of crystal samples caused by the characteristic of twin crystal of the samples. Nevertheless, by comparing their PXRD patterns, thermogravimetry curves, and elemental analyses results to those of coordination polymers 2 and 4, we conclude that coordination polymers 3 and 5 shall have similar host-guest structures to that of 2 and 4.

elements.content: The pristine coordination polymer 1 was obtained through the solvothermal reaction of Cd­(NO3)2, tpt, and 1,4-H2pda (a). Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the C2/c space group and exhibits a supramolecular layer structure (b). The asymmetric unit of 1 is composed of one Cd­(II) ion with half occupancy, half a tpt ligand, half a 1,4-pda2– anion, one coordinated water molecule, half of free tpt ligand, and one free water molecule. Cd­(II) center is coordinated by two carboxyl oxygen atoms from two different 1,4-pda2– ligands, two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from two tpt ligands, and two coordinated water molecules (Figure S1a). Cd–O bond lengths range from 2.264 to 2.366 Å, and the Cd–N bond length is 2.353 Å, which are in normal ranges according to the literature. The 1,4-pda2– anions exhibit a chair-shaped configuration with paralleling carboxylate groups, and both of carboxylate groups adopt monodentate coordination mode to link two Cd­(II) ions separated by a distance of 11.157 Å. It is worth noting that only two pyridyl groups in each tpt ligand take part in the coordination, and the residue uncoordinated group presents considerable obvious dihedral angle with the plane constructed by three pyridyl nitrogen atoms (the angle is 30.60° in Figure S1d). Then, Cd­(II) ions are linked with tpt and 1,4-pda2– ligands as 4-connected nodes to generate 2D layers with 44 grid (c), which present AAA stacking modes to leave one-dimensional channels along the b-axis with rectangular aperture (6.975 Å × 9.599 Å) between the layers. The interlayer space is accommodated by free tpt ligands through π–π stacking interactions between the coordinated and free tpt ligands with a intermolecular distance of 3.486 Å (b).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Structural Description

The pristine coordination polymer 1 was obtained through the solvothermal reaction of Cd(NO3)2, tpt, and 1,4-H2pda (a). Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the C2/c space group and exhibits a supramolecular layer structure (b). The asymmetric unit of 1 is composed of one Cd(II) ion with half occupancy, half a tpt ligand, half a 1,4-pda2- anion, one coordinated water molecule, half of free tpt ligand, and one free water molecule. Cd(II) center is coordinated by two carboxyl oxygen atoms from two different 1,4-pda2- ligands, two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from two tpt ligands, and two coordinated water molecules (Figure S1a). Cd-O bond lengths range from 2.264 to 2.366 Å, and the Cd-N bond length is 2.353 Å, which are in normal ranges according to the literature. The 1,4-pda2- anions exhibit a chair-shaped configuration with paralleling carboxylate groups, and both of carboxylate groups adopt monodentate coordination mode to link two Cd(II) ions separated by a distance of 11.157 Å. It is worth noting that only two pyridyl groups in each tpt ligand take part in the coordination, and the residue uncoordinated group presents considerable obvious dihedral angle with the plane constructed by three pyridyl nitrogen atoms (the angle is 30.60° in Figure S1d). Then, Cd(II) ions are linked with tpt and 1,4-pda2- ligands as 4-connected nodes to generate 2D layers with 44 grid (c), which present AAA stacking modes to leave one-dimensional channels along the b-axis with rectangular aperture (6.975 Å × 9.599 Å) between the layers. The interlayer space is accommodated by free tpt ligands through π-π stacking interactions between the coordinated and free tpt ligands with a intermolecular distance of 3.486 Å (b).

elements.content: (a) The components used for the assembly of coordination polymers. (b) The host framework of 1 from the stacking of 2D monolayers. The free tpt ligands between the layers are shown in green, and the van der Waals surface of the channel is presented in yellow. (c) The 2D monolayer in 1. (d) The framework structure of 2–5. The PAHs guest molecules are shown in green, and the van der Waals surface of the channel is presented in yellow. (e) The 2D bilayer in 2–5.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) The components used for the assembly of coordination polymers. (b) The host framework of 1 from the stacking of 2D monolayers. The free tpt ligands between the layers are shown in green, and the van der Waals surface of the channel is presented in yellow. (c) The 2D monolayer in 1. (d) The framework structure of 2-5. The PAHs guest molecules are shown in green, and the van der Waals surface of the channel is presented in yellow. (e) The 2D bilayer in 2-5.

elements.content: Considering the host–guest structure features of 1, it could be a good host prototype for constructing HGCT based LCPs, since efficient donor–acceptor system may be achieved through the anchoring of electron-rich PAH molecules between layers to interact with the electron-deficient tpt motifs. Motivated by this expectation, coordination polymers 2–5 have been successfully obtained by introducing different PAH guests, which exhibits unexpected structures but desired properties.
elements.clean_text: Considering the host-guest structure features of 1, it could be a good host prototype for constructing HGCT based LCPs, since efficient donor-acceptor system may be achieved through the anchoring of electron-rich PAH molecules between layers to interact with the electron-deficient tpt motifs. Motivated by this expectation, coordination polymers 2-5 have been successfully obtained by introducing different PAH guests, which exhibits unexpected structures but desired properties.

elements.content: Although 2 and 4 crystallize in different space group from the view of crystallography, their structures are quite similar in the perspective of host–guest architectures. Therefore, only a structure description of 2 is demonstrated in detail as follows. For 2, the asymmetric unit contains two Cd­(II) ions, two 1,4-pda2– anions, two tpt, and one free triphenylene. Both of Cd­(II) ions adopt a distorted pentagonal bipyramid coordination geometry, which are defined by five carboxyl oxygen atoms from three 1,4-pda2– anions and two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from two tpt ligands (Figure S1b, and in that of 4, coronene is instead of triphenylene, as shown in Figure S1c). Cd–O bond lengths range from 2.364 to 2.482 Å, and Cd–N bond lengths range from 2.357 to 2.367 Å, which are normal to those reported in the literature. Different from that of 1, the residue uncoordinated pyridyl group from one tpt ligand presents almost parallel with the plane constructed by three pyridyl nitrogen atoms (Figure S1e). The backbone of 1,4-pda2– adopts a chair-shape configuration, and the carboxylate groups adopt chelating and chelating–bridging coordination modes to link two crystallographic independent Cd­(II) ions to form binuclear secondary building unit (SBU). Then the SBUs are connected via 1,4-pda2– ligands and tpt to generate bilayer structures (e). These layered patterns adopt AAA packing modes to leave one-dimensional channels with rectangular aperture (6.755 Å × 9.411 Å) between the layers. As expected, triphenylene introduced as guest occupies the channels (d). The close packing of the layer and the guest triphenylene (3.337 Å) indicates stronger interlayer π–π stacking interactions than that in coordination polymer 1.
elements.clean_text: Although 2 and 4 crystallize in different space group from the view of crystallography, their structures are quite similar in the perspective of host-guest architectures. Therefore, only a structure description of 2 is demonstrated in detail as follows. For 2, the asymmetric unit contains two Cd(II) ions, two 1,4-pda2- anions, two tpt, and one free triphenylene. Both of Cd(II) ions adopt a distorted pentagonal bipyramid coordination geometry, which are defined by five carboxyl oxygen atoms from three 1,4-pda2- anions and two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from two tpt ligands (Figure S1b, and in that of 4, coronene is instead of triphenylene, as shown in Figure S1c). Cd-O bond lengths range from 2.364 to 2.482 Å, and Cd-N bond lengths range from 2.357 to 2.367 Å, which are normal to those reported in the literature. Different from that of 1, the residue uncoordinated pyridyl group from one tpt ligand presents almost parallel with the plane constructed by three pyridyl nitrogen atoms (Figure S1e). The backbone of 1,4-pda2- adopts a chair-shape configuration, and the carboxylate groups adopt chelating and chelating-bridging coordination modes to link two crystallographic independent Cd(II) ions to form binuclear secondary building unit (SBU). Then the SBUs are connected via 1,4-pda2- ligands and tpt to generate bilayer structures (e). These layered patterns adopt AAA packing modes to leave one-dimensional channels with rectangular aperture (6.755 Å × 9.411 Å) between the layers. As expected, triphenylene introduced as guest occupies the channels (d). The close packing of the layer and the guest triphenylene (3.337 Å) indicates stronger interlayer π-π stacking interactions than that in coordination polymer 1.

elements.content: By comparing the structures of 1–5, it is noticed that the layer network in coordination polymers 2–5 shows guest-dependent structure features. Coordination polymer 1 shows a 2D monolayer structure with tpt as guest while 2–5 reveal 2D bilayer structures with PAHs as guests. The introduction of PAHs in 2 and 4 decreases the interlayer distance, compared with that of 1, which confirms the enhanced host–guest interactions that benefits the bondage and stabilization of the whole network. Owing to their critical role in the assembly of coordination polymers with different layer structures, tpt and PAHs guests can be defined as “templates” or structure-directing agents (SDA). All these results suggest that PAH guest molecules play vital roles in the host–guest engineering of this system.
elements.clean_text: By comparing the structures of 1-5, it is noticed that the layer network in coordination polymers 2-5 shows guest-dependent structure features. Coordination polymer 1 shows a 2D monolayer structure with tpt as guest while 2-5 reveal 2D bilayer structures with PAHs as guests. The introduction of PAHs in 2 and 4 decreases the interlayer  distance, compared with that of 1, which confirms the enhanced host-guest interactions that benefits the bondage and stabilization of the whole network. Owing to their critical role in the assembly of coordination polymers with different layer structures, tpt and PAHs guests can be defined as "templates" or structure-directing agents (SDA). All these results suggest that PAH guest molecules play vital roles in the host-guest engineering of this system.

elements.content: In addition to the structural characterization, thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) of 1–5 were carried out to examine their thermal stability. The TG profile of 1 presents two weight loss stages: the first weight loss is 6.55% in the temperature ranging from 83 to 165 °C, which can be ascribed to the loss of coordinated and free water molecules (calcd 7.2%), and then the residual framework keeps no weight loss and begins to decomposes until 287 °C. In contrast, the TG curves of 2–5 present no weight loss stages until 350 °C, which is consistent with the absence of the coordinated and free solvents from the crystal structures (Figure S2). Moreover, after the introduction of these readily sublimated PAH molecules into the host network, these PAH molecules are retained very well between the interlayers and sharply removed along with the decomposition of framework. It is due to their strong π–π interactions with electron-deficient tpt that further improve the thermostability of these materials.
elements.clean_text: In addition to the structural characterization, thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) of 1-5 were carried out to examine their thermal stability. The TG profile of 1 presents two weight loss stages: the first weight loss is 6.55% in the temperature ranging from 83 to 165 °C, which can be ascribed to the loss of coordinated and free water molecules (calcd 7.2%), and then the residual framework keeps no weight loss and begins to decomposes until 287 °C. In contrast, the TG curves of 2-5 present no weight loss stages until 350 °C, which is consistent with the absence of the coordinated and free solvents from the crystal structures (Figure S2). Moreover, after the introduction of these readily sublimated PAH molecules into the host network, these PAH molecules are retained very well between the interlayers and sharply removed along with the decomposition of framework. It is due to their strong π-π interactions with electron-deficient tpt that further improve the thermostability of these materials.

elements.content: Cheeringly, these samples remain unchanged in air for a long time as expected (Figure S3). To gain better insight into their stability, they are soaked in common solvents, such as ethanol, methanol, acetonitrile, DMF, DMA, and water. The results suggest that 2–5 keep good crystalline and remarkable stability toward common organic solvents and even water, which can be proved by the PXRD measurement for samples immersed into kinds of solvents (Figure S4). In contrast, 1 gradually loses its crystalline and shows poor stability toward all these solvents. Thus, their differences in stability can be attributed to the introduction of PAHs, which leads to the framework more hydrophobic and stable due to the strong π–π stacking interactions.
elements.clean_text: Cheeringly, these samples remain unchanged in air for a long time as expected (Figure S3). To gain better insight into their stability, they are soaked in common solvents, such as ethanol, methanol, acetonitrile, DMF, DMA, and water. The results suggest that 2-5 keep good crystalline and remarkable stability toward  common organic solvents and even water, which can be proved by the PXRD measurement for samples immersed into kinds of solvents (Figure S4). In contrast, 1 gradually loses its crystalline and shows poor stability toward all these solvents. Thus, their differences in stability can be attributed to the introduction of PAHs, which leads to the framework more hydrophobic and stable due to the strong π-π stacking interactions.

elements.content: The successful combinations of electron-rich PAH guests and the electron-deficient tpt motifs favor to the formation of donor–acceptor system, which makes the resultant coordination polymers 2–5 luminescent materials with HGCT based emissions. Therefore, the photophysical properties of these coordination polymers were investigated systematically to explore their potential applications in luminophores, such as solid light-emitting diodes.
elements.clean_text:
Photophysical Properties

The successful combinations of electron-rich PAH guests and the electron-deficient tpt motifs favor to the formation of donor-acceptor system, which makes the resultant coordination polymers 2-5 luminescent materials with HGCT based emissions. Therefore, the photophysical properties of these coordination polymers were investigated systematically to explore their potential applications in  luminophores, such as solid light-emitting diodes.

elements.content: As shown in a, the crystals of 2–5 are colorful, which are quite different from that of 1 (colorless) and the corresponding guests. Color of samples 2–5 indicate the presence of adsorption bands in visible light region in contrast to that of 1, which indicates their distinct adsorption behaviors. In detail, the UV–vis absorption spectra of 1–5 (Figure S5) show that 1 presents no absorptions bands in the visible light region (>400 nm). For 2–5, broad absorption bands from 350 to 650 nm are consistent with their visible colors. In addition, the adsorption bands of these LCPs are different from that of the corresponding guest (Figure S6). Hence, the changes in spectra indicate the formation of donor–acceptor systems between the electron-rich PAH guests and electron-deficient tpt blocks, which further proves HGCT interactions.
elements.clean_text: As shown in a, the crystals of 2-5 are colorful, which are quite different from that of 1 (colorless) and the corresponding guests. Color  of samples 2-5 indicate the presence of adsorption bands in visible light region in contrast to that of 1, which indicates their distinct adsorption behaviors. In detail, the UV-vis absorption spectra of 1-5 (Figure S5) show that 1 presents no absorptions bands in the visible light region (>400 nm). For 2-5, broad absorption bands from 350 to 650 nm are consistent with their visible colors. In addition, the adsorption bands of these LCPs are different from that of the corresponding guest (Figure S6). Hence, the changes in spectra indicate the formation of donor-acceptor systems between the electron-rich PAH guests and electron-deficient tpt blocks, which further proves HGCT interactions.

elements.content: (a) Optical (middle) and luminescent (bottom) images of crystals of coordination polymers 1–5. The emission of the crystal of 1 is too weak to be identified. (b) Normalized emission spectra of 1–5 excited at 370 nm. (c) CIE coordinates for 1–5 according to their relevant emission data.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Optical (middle) and luminescent  (bottom) images of crystals of coordination polymers 1-5. The emission of the crystal of 1 is too weak to be identified. (b) Normalized emission spectra of 1-5 excited at 370 nm. (c) CIE coordinates for 1-5 according to their relevant emission data.

elements.content: Upon the presence of HGCT interactions in the 2–5, their photoluminescent emissions were further investigated. As shown in b, compared with that of 1 and the corresponding guest (Figure S7), coordination polymers 2–5 exhibit broad single emission bands, which is the characteristic of CT based emissions. The emission maxima reveal obvious guest dependent features covering a wide range from 500 nm for 2 to 640 nm for 5, under the excitation at 370 nm (). Compared with that of 1 (λem‑max = 450 nm when excited at 330 nm), all of 2–5 exhibit a bathochromic shift in different degrees. The large Stokes shifts of coordination polymers indicate efficient CT process of the exciplex composed of electron acceptor (host triazine) and electron donors (PAH molecules). In addition, the emissions of 2–5 cover a wide range from green to red in the Commission Internationale de L’Eclairage (CIE) chromaticity diagram (c and ), which proves the advantage of HGCT based LCPs as luminophores for distinct emissions by modulating donor/acceptors.
elements.clean_text: Upon the presence of HGCT interactions in the 2-5, their photoluminescent emissions were further investigated. As shown in b, compared with that of 1 and the corresponding guest (Figure S7), coordination polymers 2-5 exhibit broad single emission bands, which is the characteristic of CT based emissions. The emission maxima reveal obvious guest dependent features covering a wide range from 500 nm for 2 to 640 nm for 5, under the excitation at 370 nm (). Compared with that of 1 (λem-max = 450 nm when excited at 330 nm), all of 2-5 exhibit a bathochromic shift in different degrees. The large Stokes shifts of coordination polymers indicate efficient CT process of the exciplex composed of electron acceptor (host triazine) and electron donors (PAH molecules). In addition, the emissions of 2-5 cover a wide range from green to red in the Commission Internationale de L'Eclairage (CIE) chromaticity diagram (c and ), which proves the advantage of HGCT based LCPs as luminophores for distinct emissions by modulating donor/acceptors.

elements.content:
Summary of Solid-State Luminescent Data for <bold>1</bold>–<bold>5</bold> coordination polymer λex (nm) λem‑max (nm) CIE guest IP (eV) Φfl (%) av τ (ns) 1 330 450 (0.17, 0.16) not calculated 5.49 2 370 499 (0.22, 0.49) 8.09 30.80 17.51 3 370 570 (0.44, 0.52) 7.55 2.40 19.77 4 370 579 (0.48, 0.51) 7.44 0.83 23.55 5 370 648 (0.62, 0.36) 7.03 0.71 11.70

Ionization potential data obtained from ref .

For better understanding of the determining factors of the emissions of these LCPs for performance targeted modulations, the guest-dependent emission behaviors were further investigated ( and ). Well-fitted linear relationships are obtained between the ionization potentials (IP) of the guest molecules and the emission maxima of 2–5. It is just observed in few LCPs and cocrystal systems, in which the linear relationships between the IP and λem‑max are shown in a shorter range. This might be attributed to the more rigid framework of 2–5 with the effective host–guest interactions, which minimizes the displacement between the guest and host that affects their overlay and the corresponding charge transfer interactions. Furthermore, these features could benefit the emission targeted modulation of these LCPs in a more rational way by selecting guests with proper IPs.
elements.clean_text: For better understanding of the determining factors of the emissions of these LCPs for performance targeted modulations, the guest-dependent emission behaviors were further investigated ( and ). Well-fitted linear relationships are obtained between the ionization potentials (IP) of the guest molecules and the emission maxima of 2-5. It is just observed in few LCPs and cocrystal systems, in which the linear relationships between the IP and λem-max are shown in a shorter range. This might be attributed to the more rigid framework of 2-5 with the effective host-guest interactions, which minimizes the displacement between the guest and host that affects their overlay and the corresponding charge transfer interactions. Furthermore, these features could benefit the emission targeted modulation of these LCPs in a more rational way by selecting guests with proper IPs.

elements.content: Linear correlation between the emission maxima of 2–5 and the ionization potential (IP) of corresponding guests.
elements.clean_text: 3  Linear correlation between the emission maxima of 2-5 and the ionization potential (IP) of corresponding guests.

elements.content: On the other hand, the absolute quantum yields (Φ) of these coordination polymers were further determined by the integration sphere method. The Φ of 1 cannot be obtained because of its weak emission, while the Φ values are 30.8% for 2, 2.40% for 3, 0.83% for 4, and 0.71% for 5. More importantly, the Φ values of 2–5 reveal obvious decreasing trend along with the decrease IPs of the guests. Upon encapsulation of PAHs with different ionization potentials, 2–5 present distinct emission wavelengths, which is ascribed to the different CT degrees between tpt and the PAHs. That is to say, the strong electron-donating property of perylene (IP = 7.03 eV) and coronene (IP = 7.44 eV) may quench the CT based emission of coordination polymers with the contribution of the radical ion pair state (<1%), while the relative modest electron-donating property of triphenylene (IP = 8.09 eV) provides sufficient electron-donating capabilities to form an exciplex, which leads to a higher quantum yield of 2. These explanations are well supported by the fluorescent lifetime (τ) values of these coordination polymers ( and Figure S8) because an increase–decrease trend can be observed along with the decrease of IP of the guests, which may be attributed to the deactivation of different emission species. All these results suggest that the emission behaviors (Φ and τ) of the HGCT based LCPs could be modulated flexibility according to the regulation of the donating and accepting capacities of the donor and acceptors.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, the absolute quantum yields (Φ) of these coordination polymers were further determined by the integration sphere method. The Φ of 1 cannot be obtained because of its weak emission, while the Φ values are 30.8% for 2, 2.40% for 3, 0.83% for 4, and 0.71% for 5. More importantly, the Φ values of 2-5 reveal obvious decreasing trend along with the decrease IPs of the guests. Upon encapsulation of PAHs with different ionization potentials, 2-5 present distinct emission wavelengths, which is ascribed to the different CT degrees between tpt and the PAHs. That is to say, the strong electron-donating property of perylene (IP = 7.03 eV) and coronene (IP = 7.44 eV) may quench the CT based emission of coordination polymers with the contribution of the radical ion pair state (<1%), while the relative modest electron-donating property of triphenylene (IP = 8.09 eV) provides sufficient electron-donating capabilities to form an exciplex, which leads to a higher quantum yield of 2. These explanations are well supported by the fluorescent lifetime (τ) values of these coordination polymers ( and Figure S8) because an increase-decrease trend can be observed along with the decrease of IP of the guests, which may be attributed to the deactivation of different emission species. All these results suggest that the emission behaviors (Φ and τ) of the HGCT based LCPs could be modulated flexibility according to the regulation of the donating and accepting capacities of the donor and acceptors.

elements.content: In summary, through the host–guest engineering of coordination polymers utilizing the interactions between the electron-deficient tpt molecules and electron-rich PAHs, we have developed a new LCP system showing readily tunable HGCT based emission properties. The resulted coordination polymers reveal guest-dependent structures and good stabilities, which indicates the important roles of host–guest interactions on the assembly process and structure modulation. More importantly, benefiting from the unambiguous guest to host charge transfer process, the emission properties of coordination polymers can be tuned in a wide range by the rational selection of guest molecules. All these features make these coordination polymers good candidates as luminophores. In addition, this engineering of host–guest architectures can be a promising method for the structure and property modulations of LCPs as potential luminophores.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, through the host-guest engineering of coordination polymers utilizing the interactions between the electron-deficient tpt molecules and electron-rich PAHs, we have developed a new LCP system showing readily tunable HGCT based emission properties. The resulted coordination polymers reveal guest-dependent structures and good  stabilities, which indicates the important roles of host-guest interactions on the assembly process and structure modulation. More importantly, benefiting from the unambiguous guest to host charge transfer process, the emission properties of coordination polymers can be tuned in a wide range by the rational selection of guest molecules. All these features make these coordination polymers good candidates as luminophores. In addition, this engineering of host-guest architectures can be a promising method for the structure and property modulations of LCPs as potential luminophores.

cln_elements.content:
For the syntheses of [Cd­(tpt)­(1,4-pda)­(H2O)2]·(tpt)·(H2O)2 (1), a mixture of Cd­(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol), 1,4-H2pda (0.1 mmol), and tpt (0.05 mmol) in DMF (6 mL), H2O (2 mL), and ethanol (2 mL) mixed solvents was placed in a 20 mL glass vial and sealed. The vial was heated at 95 °C for 24 h, and then colorless crystals were obtained (65% yield based on tpt). EA Calcd (%) for C46H40CdN12O8: C, 55.18; H, 4.03; N, 16.79. Found: C, 55.14; H, 4.45; N, 16.62. FT-IR (KBr, 3500–4000 cm–1): 3546 (m), 3431 (m), 3048 (m), 1571 (s), 1516 (s), 1419 (m), 1370 (m), 1315 (m), 1146 (w), 1062 (w), 1012 (w), 803 (s), 713 (s), 665 (s), 642 (s).

For the syntheses of [Cd2(tpt)2(1,4-pda)2]·guest (2–5), similar procedures to that of 1 were applied, with the introduction of corresponding guest (0.05 mmol) into the reaction systems. For 2 (guest = triphenylene), light green crystals were obtained. Yield: 60% (based on tpt). EA Calcd (%) for C74H52Cd2N12O8: C, 60.79; H, 3.58; N, 11.50. Found: C, 60.92; H, 3.81; N, 11.03. FT-IR (KBr, 3500–4000 cm–1): 3079 (m), 3050 (m), 3035 (m), 2970 (m), 2931 (m), 1611 (m), 1566 (s), 1517 (s), 1439 (m), 1373 (m), 1313 (m), 1140 (w), 1061 (w), 1012 (w), 800 (s), 752 (s), 667 (s), 642 (s). For 3 (guest = pyrene), orange crystals were obtained. Yield: 50% (based on tpt). EA Calcd for C72H50Cd2N12O8: C, 62.22; H, 3.51; N, 11.70. Found: C, 62.54; H, 3.26; N, 11.17. FT-IR (KBr, 3500–4000 cm–1): 3050 (m), 3032 (m), 2965 (m), 2928 (m), 1610 (m), 1552 (s), 1511 (s), 1434 (m), 1383 (m), 1313 (m), 1145 (w), 1060 (w), 1015 (w), 797 (s), 769 (s), 667 (s), 642 (s). For 4 (guest = coronene), orange crystals were obtained. Yield: 62% (based on tpt). EA Calcd for C80H52Cd2N12O8: C, 62.63; H, 3.41; N, 10.96. Found: C, 62.24; H, 3.56; N, 9.77. FT-IR (KBr, 3500–4000 cm–1): 3050 (m), 2967 (m), 2930 (m), 1611 (m), 1566 (s), 1516 (s), 1440 (m), 1385 (m), 1313 (m), 1142 (w), 1064 (w), 1012 (w), 799 (s), 726 (s), 667 (s), 642 (s). For 5 (guest = perylene), red crystals were obtained. Yield: 55% (based on tpt). EA Calcd for C76H54Cd2N12O8: C, 61.33; H, 3.66; N, 11.29. Found: C, 62.04; H, 3.35; N, 10.57. FT-IR (KBr, 3500–4000 cm–1): 3050 (m), 3030 (m), 2962 (m), 2928 (m), 1609 (m), 1557 (s), 1517 (s), 1437 (m), 1373 (m), 1313 (m), 1140 (w), 1061 (w), 1013 (w), 799 (s), 766 (s), 667 (s), 642 (s).

The vial was heated at 95 °C for 24 h, and then colorless crystals were obtained (65% yield based on tpt). EA Calcd (%) for C46H40CdN12O8: C, 55.18; H, 4.03; N, 16.79. cln_elements.content: In addition to the structural characterization, thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) of 1–5 were carried out to examine their thermal stability. The TG profile of 1 presents two weight loss stages: the first weight loss is 6.55% in the temperature ranging from 83 to 165 °C, which can be ascribed to the loss of coordinated and free water molecules (calcd 7.2%), and then the residual framework keeps no weight loss and begins to decomposes until 287 °C. In contrast, the TG curves of 2–5 present no weight loss stages until 350 °C, which is consistent with the absence of the coordinated and free solvents from the crystal structures (Figure S2). Moreover, after the introduction of these readily sublimated PAH molecules into the host network, these PAH molecules are retained very well between the interlayers and sharply removed along with the decomposition of framework. It is due to their strong π–π interactions with electron-deficient tpt that further improve the thermostability of these materials.
cln_elements.clean_text: In addition to the structural characterization, thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) of 1-5 were carried out to examine their thermal stability. The TG profile of 1 presents two weight loss stages: the first weight loss is 6.55% in the temperature ranging from 83 to 165 °C, which can be ascribed to the loss of coordinated and free water molecules (calcd 7.2%), and then the residual framework keeps no weight loss and begins to decomposes until 287 °C. In contrast, the TG curves of 2-5 present no weight loss stages until 350 °C, which is consistent with the absence of the coordinated and free solvents from the crystal structures (Figure S2). Moreover, after the introduction of these readily sublimated PAH molecules into the host network, these PAH molecules are retained very well between the interlayers and sharply removed along with the decomposition of framework. It is due to their strong π-π interactions with electron-deficient tpt that further improve the thermostability of these materials.

decomposition temperature.type: loss of coordinated and free water molecules

decomposition temperature.condition: absence of the coordinated and free solvents from the crystal structures
